Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Promoting or Suppressing Solid-State Phase Transformation via Interface Control
Award.AbstractNarration: NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The renewable energy future, from electric vehicles to rechargeable personal devices, strongly depends on Li-ion energy storage technology. This project focuses on understanding and controlling processes in electrode materials that can allow for greater storage capacities but typically suffer from severe degradation due to changes in their solid-state structures. Most of the research, which involves both experimental and computational approaches, is designed to promote or suppress the solid-state phase change of the electrode by depositing a coating layer to impose chemical and mechanical constraints. The specific findings from this project, especially on suppressing the phase change, will enable low-cost, abundant, cobalt-free, high-capacity conversion electrodes with long cycle life for lithium-based batteries that are used in a variety of applications. The scientific advancement will stimulate the broader materials research community to explore the influence of interfacial controls on phase competition for many materials systems. Knowledge transfer is occurring through both public dissemination and direct interactions with industrial and national lab partners through the PIs’ research network. Furthermore, these research activities serve as an educational platform for students at all levels and from different backgrounds to develop interdisciplinary expertise by directly experiencing both computational and experimental methods through this collaborative research. <br/><br/>TECHNICAL DETAILS: Pursuing both high lithium storage capacity and reversibility is a dilemma but also a crucial need as the renewable energy future, from electric vehicles to renewable power, strongly depends on Li-ion energy storage technology. This project will explore a new design principle to extend reversible intercalation reactions to higher lithium capacity by using surface modification and conformal coatings to suppress the irreversible solid-state phase transformations. Efforts at Michigan State University focus on developing a Density Functional Theory (DFT)-based multiscale modeling method to accurately predict phase evolution in the coated electrode. Efforts at University of Maryland will precisely control the surface layer with atomic layer deposition (ALD) to vary its chemistry, modulus, and thickness and perform electrochemical characterization. The collaborative efforts will determine atomistic origins of the competition between conversion and intercalation reactions during lithiation of conversion cathode materials and determine the coupled chemical-mechanical effect of the nanoscale coating layer on the competition of the two reactions. The scientific impact of this project goes beyond improved life and performance of conversion-type materials to the fundamental opportunity to understand how a material’s bulk reactions can be modulated through carefully designed interfacial control layers. Faculty from both Universities are working with students at all levels and from different backgrounds to expand educational outcomes to a broader research community.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project involves Brown University (Brown) and the University of Maryland (UMD) The original main objective of the project is to develop fundamental knowledge to understand and control the phase transformation process in conversion electrode materials, which can store more lithium but typically suffer from severe degradation due to the phase change. Experiments (performed at UMD) show that thin protection layers on FeOF particles cause a delay in the lithiation-induced conversion reaction to form FeO and LiF, but the origin of this has been unknown. Atomic simulations were performed (at Brown) to understand the competition between intercalation vs conversion reactions suggests that Li intercalation in forming rutile LiFeOF is followed by phase change to a rock salt LiFeOF structure before intercalation is completed, which accelerates nucleation of new conversion reaction products (FeO and LiF). Since the rutile to rock salt phase change involves structural change and volume expansion, compressive stress can delay the phase change. This provides a plausible, theory-based explanation for how thin protection layers can delay the onset of conversion reaction during lithiation. This work reveals a new, intermediate step (rutile=>rocksalt) in the Li-FeOF conversion reaction, forging an important direction for computational research in advanced batteries.

A similar modeling approach has also been used to explore more sustainable high-performance solid electrolytes, which can be paired with the high capacity conversion electrodes for next-generation energy-storage systems with high energy density and safety. Through a joint experiment (at UMD) and modeling (at Brown), we demonstrated that molecule-engineered cellulose nanofibrils (derived from woods) through the insertion of copper and lithium ions can be used as a high-performance solid polymer electrolyte that presents record-high ionic conductivity, wide electrochemical stability window, low activation energy, and scalability. More importantly, we uncovered the accurate atomic structures of the lithium and copper inserted cellulose nanofibrils system and the lithium-ion conduction mechanism therein, providing the fundamental reasons for the highest lithium-ion conductivity among all the solid polymer electrolytes ever reported during the last four decades.

The specific findings from this project are directly relevant to the development of improved electrodes and electrolytes for high-energy density lithium batteries for hybrid and electric vehicles. Conversion materials are very attractive candidates for battery electrodes due to their high energy storage capacity. Our coated conversion reaction electrode approaches may open the door to enhanced reversibility to harness more of the energy storage capacity of conversion materials. Pairing them with newly invented wood-derived high-performance solid electrolytes points to new directions for next-generation safer and high-energy storage systems.  The major outcome/achievement of the project, including important method developments and scientific discoveries, had been documented in publications and presented at major conferences. The overall understanding of phase change, ion transport, and chemical-mechanical coupling in ionic material has already made an impact on the battery community.
